Description: A pottery flask in the form of a satyr, modelled in the round. He squats on the ground, holding a striated drinking-cup between his knees with both hands. He has a frowning brow and receding hair: a deep V-shaped plain element at the rear, running from his head to mid-back, may be long hair, or the tail of a hood. A short-necked opening rises from the top of his head and is flanked by small ring-handles. Two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, covered with a mottled red-brown slip.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Ptolemaic, last third of the fourth century BC. Comparanda: Close to the blurred Török 1995: no. 136, perhaps from the same mould-series. Close: Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, e.ga.2925.1943.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3339)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
